item.title: Some things I learned in a Hacker Rank exercise
item.description: A couple of days ago I subscribed to Hacker Hank, a website specialized in provide interview exercises. The site is as a better version of Code Jam, with the possibility to Compile & Run the code, as well as running several test cases. Talking with friends about one of them proposed a interesting puzzle called Find the Running Median. This is a good problem because it is easy to understand and tricky to implement.

item.title: Real Programmers Don't Use Java
item.description: When I was a newbie (and a wanna-be) I enjoyed reading “Real Programmers Don’t Use Pascal”, a satiric text that influenced and encouraged me into the path of “C/C++ enlightenment”, most even than K&R’s book. Since then I thought that being a “Real Programmer” was something close to everything one needs to know to get (hard) things done (quickly). Being a “Quiche Eater” was, in couterpart, comparable to nothing. Real Programmers solve real problems!

item.title: Using TodoList and Microsoft Project together
item.description: The next article about bits is still in the oven. Taking vacation (40 days) had drop me out of ideas! At the moment, I can explain the tips and tricks using TodoList to manage my team and synchronize my tasks in a Microsoft Project timesheet. The reasons why I am using TodoList are kind of obvious: it does everything I need to organize my day to day tasks and it is portable.

item.title: How to run anything as a service
item.description: The biggest advantage running an application as a service, interactive or not, is to allow its start before a logon be performed. An example that happens to me is the need of debugging a GINA. In order to do this, I need the Visual Studio remote debugger be started before logon. The easiest and fastest solution is to run Msvcmon, the server part of debugging, as a service. Today I’ve figured out a pretty interesting shortcut to achieve it.

item.title: MouseTool
item.description: Well, as most of you already know, I really don’t like mice. Nevertheless I respect the users who use it and like it. That is the reason why I am writing a little more about it. This time, I going to show a program I use every day: MouseTool, for the users who does not use the mouse and like it. The program main purpose is to avoid clicking the mouse, simulating a click every time the user stops to move the cursor.
